abstract.p: Leonard Klein, letter, responds to May 7 article that cited patients' demands for unnecessary drug treatment as one source of waste in health care system; blames drug company ads that tout expensive drugs, urging consumers to 'ask your doctor' (M)

block.p: ''Patients Can Burn Cash, Too'' (May 7), rightly points out that one cause of waste in the health care system stems from patients who demand unnecessary drug treatment. However, one must acknowledge that pharmaceutical companies are largely responsible for this situation. There are no health-related benefits from the many newspaper and TV ads that tout expensive drugs, and then direct the reader or listener to ''ask your doctor.''

''Patients Can Burn Cash, Too'' (May 7), rightly points out that one cause of waste in the health care system stems from patients who demand unnecessary drug treatment. However, one must acknowledge that pharmaceutical companies are largely responsible for this situation. There are no health-related benefits from the many newspaper and TV ads that tout expensive drugs, and then direct the reader or listener to ''ask your doctor.''
Such advertising causes patients to pressure doctors for drugs that may not be necessary, but that help the companies' bottom lines.
